title: Colours
summary: Colour is a powerful tool in design, shaping hierarchy, guiding attention, and reinforcing brand identity. In Green, colours work alongside whitespace and typography to create clarity and balance.

columns.text: Based on our brand colors, we have developed a comprehensive palette of tints for each one. These extended palettes allow for greater versatility and nuance, ensuring consistency and depth across all visual elements.
Colors in Green are translated to work in both light and dark mode. This adaptation preserves contrast, readability, and the overall visual integrity of the interface.
The colors are structured into four groups - background, content, border and state. Backgrounds are divided into three levels.
This structured approach ensures clear visual hierarchy, making it easy to design interfaces with depth and contrast while maintaining flexibility across different layouts.

columns.title: Background colours and levels
columns.content:
Background colours are grouped by their level in the interface:  
  
**L1** – the base layer of the screen  
**L2** – structural layers like cards and modals  
**L3** – backgrounds for components like buttons and inputs   
  
This structure supports clarity, consistency, and a clear visual hierarchy.

columns.title: Content colours
columns.content: Content colours are used for text, icons, and other foreground elements. They guarantee readability and clear contrast against the background.

columns.title: Border colours
columns.content: Border tokens are used to define the edges of components and layout sections. They help separate content and add structure to the interface.

columns.title: State colours
columns.content: State tokens provide visual feedback for interactions, ensuring consistency across components in both light and dark mode. We have defined an extensive set of tokens to support customisation across primary, secondary, and tertiary components.
